awd_titl_txt: Marangoni Transport Synergism in Mixed Surfactant Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Surfactants are compounds that lower the surface tension between two phases (for example, oil and water) and are important for a range of complex fluid products, such as laundry detergents, flooding fluids for enhanced oil recovery, and many food, pharmaceutical and consumer products. Fluid flows driven by gradients in surface tension are called "Marangoni flows" and have been well-studied in systems containing a single surfactant. However, industrially important products typically contain mixtures of surfactants. This research project considers how surfactant mixtures may produce strong cooperative or synergistic effects on these Marangoni flows. Experiments to measure these flows and the effects of the surfactants on the interfaces are being performed and compared to theories modified for these multi-component systems. While building on existing knowledge and methods, this research expands into fundamentally interesting and commercially important areas. Understanding the interactions between surfactants is a potentially powerful aid to product formulation across a host of industries.  STEM human resource infrastructure is benefitting from the research training of graduate and undergraduate students.  Additionally, middle school students are being mentored through the Carnegie Mellon University Physics Concepts Outreach Program in a project in which student-designed experiments reveal interfacial engineering concepts underlying liquid commercial product formulations.

Marangoni synergism is the creation of stronger Marangoni transport in the presence of two surfactants than is obtained from either of the two on their own, at the same interfacial tension. This synergism results from the coupled effects of thermodynamics, diffusion, flow conditions, and kinetic rate constants on Marangoni transport. This research project demonstrates this synergism and identifies the conditions that produce it. Experiments are focusing on two-component surfactants in aqueous solutions flowing past a pure oil layer and single-surfactant aqueous solutions flowing past a surfactant-containing oil film. Transient interfacial velocities are being measured as the bulk composition is changed to drive the system out of equilibrium. These transport experiments are being complemented by equilibrium interfacial tension measurements and theoretical transport modeling to identify the influence of dynamic parameters on surfactant compositions that yield Marangoni synergism. The knowledge generated by this research fills a significant knowledge gap in the literature and enables new interfacial approaches for complex fluid formulation.

por.por_cntn:
Marangoni transport is a fluid flow process that occurs whenever the surface tension of a liquid varies between different locations on its surface. Liquid flows from low surface tension to high surface tension.  Surface tension is the force that holds the surface of a liquid together. Its effects can be appreciated when a glass of water is filled over the top without spilling over the sides. Beyond this everyday observation, surface tension controls the performance of many industrial and consumer liquid products.  For example, surface tension controls how oil and water can be mixed in the form of emulsions, with applications as diverse as liquid medications, topical lotions, pesticide formulations, and many foods. Surface tension controls whether or not a coating will spread on a surface, and in that context, Marangoni transport influences whether a coating will be uniform and defect-free.  Marangoni transport also plays critical roles in advanced microcircuit cleaning processes and even influences how medications are distributed within the lung.

One of the main motivations for this work was that our society is demanding increasingly sophisticated functionality, lower toxicity and lower environmental impact from formulated liquid products. Even in existing products, industry is substituting current ingredients with new ones for environmental and health reasons. To meet the demands placed on these products, they often must become more complex in their compositions. Their design and manufacture require fundamental understanding of how the various ingredients interact with each other.  This is especially important for the surfactants that are used to control surface tension and its manifestations.  Through a combination of experimentation and theoretical modeling, this work provided new fundamental understanding of how the interactions between surfactants in a mixture control Marangoni transport.

This work introduced the concept of Marangoni transport synergism, whereby a surfactant blend may produce stronger Marangoni transport than either surfactant acting alone. It demonstrated how Marangoni synergism was related to the well-established concept of surface tension synergism.  The latter is a thermodynamic (equilibrium) concept.  Marangoni transport is controlled not only by thermodynamic factors, but also by dynamic (non-equilibrium) factors.  Theory developed through this award determined how the coupling of thermodynamic and dynamic factors control the rate and extent of Marangoni transport induced by surfactant mixtures. The new theory was combined with experiments measuring Marangoni transport with surfactant blends selected on the basis of the strength of their mutual intermolecular interactions to discover the conditions that generate Marangoni synergism. Because Marangoni transport is directly related to the rheological, or fluid mechanical, characteristics of surfaces, the Marangoni synergism work was complemented by discoveries of new mechanisms by which surfactant blend interactions or the presence of novel polymeric surfactants synthesized with well-controlled molecular structures control the rheological properties of surfaces.

This work was intellectually innovative because it went beyond the thermodynamic concept of equilibrium surface tension synergism to define and elucidate the new concept of Marangoni transport synergism. It had broader impact because it remedied a significant knowledge gap in the fundamental engineering science literature concerning the dynamics of surfaces in multicomponent surfactant systems. It will thereby enable new engineering approaches to design and manufacture complex fluid products across a wide spectrum of industries. This work contributed to the development of an expert, diverse engineering and science workforce.  It supported the research education of chemical engineering students at all university levels: four undergraduates, one Master of Science and one Doctoral student learned to design, conduct, and analyze research projects and to communicate their results. The work was conducted in an interdisciplinary setting that promoted the ability of engineers and physicists to collaborate and take advantage of their different knowledge bases and problem solving approaches. In this way, these students have become well prepared for technological careers where interdisciplinary collaboration enhances the capability to solve increasingly complex problems.
